metadata.titleEn: Atlas of pollen and spores for common plants from the east Tibetan Plateau
metadata.description: Pollen and spores extracted from sediment are considered as the important proxy in reconstructing past vegetation and climate, and which plays essential role in investigating environmental evolution during the Quaternary. Accurate identification of pollen and spore is the base for palynological research, which determines it is quite necessary to establish modern atlas for pollen and spore. Supported by the projects the Strategic Priority Research Program of Chinese Academy of Sciences “Pan-Third Pole Environment Study for a Green Silk Road (Pan-TPE)” and The Second Tibetan Plateau Scientific Expedition and Research, authors completed the vegetation and soil surveys in 2018 for the alpine meadow in the east Tibetan Plateau (including Yushu Prefecture, Changdu City, Ganzi prefecture, Naqu City) and alpine forest in the southeast Tibetan Plateau (Linzhi City) , and collected 401 specimens for anther of flowering plants and sporangium of ferns. Pollen and spores were extracted and from these specimens using the standard acid-alkali approach and acetolysis (9:1 mixture of acetic anhydride and sulphuric acid) treatment, and further were refrigerated in glycerin. More than two photographs were took for each pollen and spore type, using the LEICA-dm-2500 optical microscope and its imaging system with scale. The atlas of pollen and spore morphology will be a valuable reference for palynology research and teaching.
metadata.instructions: The photos of each sporopollen specimen are kept in a separate folder, named by species name (Latin name and Chinese name) and serial number. The sporopollen specimens of the same family are stored in the same folder, and all the files are named by Latin name and Chinese name.

background: Due to insufficient palaeo-environmental records, the vegetation history and hydrology of the Tibetan Plateau during the Last Glacial Maximum (LGM) are uncertain. Pollen extracted from sediment archives is an important proxy for past vegetation and climate reconstructions, and the relative abundances of pollen compositions (percentages or square-root transformed percentages) are usually employed in numerical analyses and quantitative reconstructions. The Tibetan Plateau is mainly covered by non-forest vegetation, including alpine meadow, alpine steppe, and alpine desert, and the modern pollen assemblages from the core high-elevation areas are dominated by herbaceous pollen taxa such as Cyperaceae, Artemisia, Chenopodiaceae, and Poaceae; while the arboreal pollen taxa have quite low abundance generally. However, arboreal pollen grains occur at high percentages in fossil pollen assemblages collected from the central Tibetan Plateau, particularly in samples with low pollen concentrations from the glacial period. Unfortunately, this can lead to problematical results when past vegetation and climate estimations are based solely on pollen percentages ignoring the variation in pollen concentrations. Many lakes are distributed across the Tibetan Plateau (ca. 1400 lakes with an area larger than 1 km2), and they are potentially ideal archives for many environmental proxies to investigate past environmental changes. Although past environmental records on the Tibetan Plateau using lacustrine sediments are abundant, most of these records are restricted to within the Holocene or the last 20 cal ka BP, while only a few records cover the last glacial-interglacial cycle entirely.
research objective: In this study, a 316-cm-long sediment core covering the last 33.8 thousand years recovered from Koucha Lake on the north-eastern Tibetan Plateau was analysed for pollen, along with total organic carbon (TOC) and total nitrogen (TN), to explore past vegetation and hydrology changes. In this study, we obtained a lacustrine sediment core covering the last 33.8 cal ka BP (with reliable chronology) from a small lake (Koucha Lake) on the north-eastern Tibetan Plateau. We investigated the changes in vegetation and hydrology based on pollen data (including aquatic pollen and algae spores) together with measurements of total nitrogen (TN) and total organic carbon (TOC) to determine the history of vegetation and hydrology during the late stage of MIS 3 and the LGM for the north-eastern Tibetan Plateau.
methods: In March 2003, a core of 560 cm length (reaching the glacial drift layer; called KC-03 in this study) was obtained from a water depth of 4.1 m from Koucha Lake, and a series of proxies analysed to investigate the histories of the lake's ecosystem and terrestrial environment since ca. 16.7 cal ka BP. Hence a second core of 316 cm (also reaching the glacial drift layer; called KC-19) was drilled from the lake centre at a water depth of 7 m (34.0105/C14 N, 97.2345/C14 E) in January 2019 using Austria's UWITEC platform coring equipment. The core was subsampled at 1 cm intervals, providing 316 samples in total and samples were preserved in the Institute of Tibetan Plateau Research, Chinese Academy of Sciences. Prior to analysis, all samples were freeze-dried. Sediment samples were analysed for pollen composition, TOC, and TN. Pollen analysis was completed on 96 samples at 3-cm intervals throughout the core, with sample weights ranging from 0.5 to 3 g depending on their pollen concentrations. One tablet of Lycopodium spores (27,637± 563 grains) was added to each sample prior to pollen extraction for calculating pollen concentration. Pollen grains were extracted using a procedure including treatments with 10% HCl, 10% NaOH, and 40% HF, followed by a 7-mm mesh sieving and acetolysis treatment (9:1 mixture of acetic anhydride and sulfuric acid).

Verification.Question: Are pollen and spore samples preserved using glycerin after acetolysis in the data collection method?

Concept Completion.Question: What are the methods used for collecting and preserving pollen samples from sediment cores?
Concept Completion.Answer: 10% HCl, 10% NaOH, 40% HF, 7-mm mesh sieving, acetolysis treatment, freeze-drying

Concept Completion.Question: What steps are involved in the preparation of pollen morphology images for a dataset?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to analyze pollen composition in sediment cores from the Tibetan Plateau?
Example.Answer: A core of 316 cm length was drilled from the center of Koucha Lake using Austria's UWITEC platform coring equipment. The core was subsampled at 1 cm intervals, providing 316 samples. Pollen grains were extracted using a procedure including treatments with 10% HCl, 10% NaOH, and 40% HF, followed by a 7-mm mesh sieving and acetolysis treatment.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge encountered when using pollen data as a proxy for past vegetation and climate reconstructions on the Tibetan Plateau?
Example.Answer: A challenge is that arboreal pollen grains occur at high percentages in fossil pollen assemblages collected from the central Tibetan Plateau, particularly in samples with low pollen concentrations from the glacial period, potentially leading to problematic results when past vegetation and climate estimations are based solely on pollen percentages.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of how pollen concentration is calculated in sediment samples for palaeo-environmental studies?
Example.Answer: One tablet of Lycopodium spores (27,637± 563 grains) was added to each sediment sample prior to pollen extraction for calculating pollen concentration.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of pollen extraction methods used in sediment studies on the Tibetan Plateau?
Feature Specification.Answer: 10% HCl, 10% NaOH, 40% HF, 7-mm mesh sieving, acetolysis treatment (9:1 mixture of acetic anhydride and sulfuric acid)

Feature Specification.Question: What specific features of pollen morphology are captured in the image collection process for pollen analysis?
What are the factors considered when selecting sampling intervals and sample weights for pollen analysis in lacustrine sediment cores?
Feature Specification.Answer: 3 cm, 0.5 to 3 g, Lycopodium spores added

Quantification.Question: How many flowering plant anther and fern sporangia specimens were collected for the pollen morphology atlas from the eastern Tibetan Plateau?
How many pollen samples were analyzed in the sediment core study from Koucha Lake to investigate past vegetation and hydrology changes?
What is the length of the sediment core obtained from Koucha Lake on the north-eastern Tibetan Plateau for analyzing past environmental changes?

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods for pollen morphology from plant specimens compare to those used for sediment core pollen analysis in terms of preparation and preservation techniques?
Comparison.Answer: The data collection for pollen morphology from plant specimens involves collecting flower anther and spore capsule samples, purifying them through acid and base treatments, and preserving them in glycerol. In contrast, sediment core pollen analysis involves subsampling sediment cores, freeze-drying samples, and using chemical treatments including HCl, NaOH, and HF, followed by sieving and acetolysis treatment to extract pollen grains for analysis.

Interpretation.Question: What can be inferred about the effectiveness of pollen concentration measurements in reconstructing past vegetation and climate from sediment cores?
Interpretation.Answer: The pollen concentrations provide essential data for past vegetation and climate reconstructions by allowing researchers to account for variations in pollen abundance, which can help to avoid misleading interpretations based solely on pollen percentages.

Interpretation.Question: How might the use of acetic anhydride and sulfuric acid in pollen extraction influence the quality and reliability of the data collected from sediment samples?
Interpretation.Answer: The use of acetic anhydride and sulfuric acid in pollen extraction likely ensures that pollen grains are well-preserved and distinct, enhancing the accuracy and reliability of identifying pollen taxa and thereby improving the quality of data for reconstructing past environmental conditions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges of accurately reconstructing past vegetation and climate using pollen data from sediment archives in the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenges stem from the uncertainty in vegetation history and hydrology during the Last Glacial Maximum (LGM) due to insufficient palaeo-environmental records. Additionally, the dominance of herbaceous pollen taxa and low abundance of arboreal pollen in modern pollen assemblages from high-elevation areas can lead to problematic results when solely relying on pollen percentages for past vegetation and climate estimations.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it important to consider both pollen percentages and pollen concentrations when analyzing fossil pollen assemblages from the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Considering both pollen percentages and pollen concentrations is crucial because relying only on pollen percentages can lead to misleading results, especially in samples with low pollen concentrations from the glacial period. High percentages of arboreal pollen grains in these samples may not accurately reflect past vegetation and climate conditions if concentration variations are ignored.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What led to the choice of specific chemical treatments and methodologies for pollen extraction in sediment core analysis from Koucha Lake?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The chosen methods, which include treatments with 10% HCl, 10% NaOH, 40% HF, and acetolysis (a 9:1 mixture of acetic anhydride and sulfuric acid), were likely selected for their efficacy in thoroughly extracting pollen grains, ensuring accurate pollen concentration calculations. The addition of Lycopodium spores for concentration calculations further supports precise quantitative analyses of the sediment samples.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the use of acid-alkali treatment and acetolysis in pollen extraction influence the accuracy and reliability of pollen concentration measurements in sediment samples?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of acid-alkali treatment and acetolysis in pollen extraction helps purify the pollen grains, which is crucial for accurate identification and concentration measurement. This method removes unwanted materials, ensuring that the pollen concentration reflects the true abundance in the sediment sample, leading to more reliable reconstruction of past vegetation and climate.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary objectives of collecting and analyzing pollen data from sediment archives on the Tibetan Plateau?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objectives of collecting and analyzing pollen data from sediment archives on the Tibetan Plateau are to reconstruct past vegetation and climate, particularly during the Last Glacial Maximum (LGM), and to understand the vegetation history and hydrology of the region.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are typically involved in the extraction and preservation of pollen grains for environmental reconstruction studies?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Pollen grains are extracted using a procedure that includes treatments with 10% HCl, 10% NaOH, and 40% HF, followed by a 7-mm mesh sieving and acetolysis treatment with a 9:1 mixture of acetic anhydride and sulfuric acid. Samples are preserved by adding glycerol and storing them in a cold environment.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can researchers ensure accurate identification and classification of pollen samples to improve the reliability of paleoenvironmental reconstructions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Accurate identification and classification of pollen samples can be ensured by creating a pollen morphology atlas using sophisticated imaging systems like the LEICA-DM-2500 optical microscope, which allows for detailed photography of pollen samples, with each specimen being photographed at least twice with scale references.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have enabled the precise identification and documentation of pollen morphology in sediments as proxies for past climate and vegetation reconstruction?
Enablement.Answer: The use of LEICA-DM-2500 optical microscopes and associated imaging systems has enabled the precise identification and documentation of pollen morphology, which is crucial for reconstructing past climate and vegetation.

Enablement.Question: How do specific chemical treatments enable the extraction and preservation of pollen grains from sediment samples for palaeo-environmental studies?
Enablement.Answer: The extraction and preservation of pollen grains are enabled by chemical treatments including acid-base purification and acetolysis using a mixture of acetic anhydride and sulfuric acid, which help in preparing clean samples for analysis.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be challenges in obtaining accurate pollen concentration data from sediment cores in the Tibetan Plateau?
Expectation.Answer: Accurate pollen concentration data can be challenging due to variations in pollen concentrations, which are particularly problematic when relying solely on pollen percentages for past vegetation and climate estimations. Additionally, the presence of high percentages of arboreal pollen grains in samples with low pollen concentrations from the glacial period could lead to misleading results.

Expectation.Question: What are the potential limitations of using a single sediment core for paleoenvironmental reconstruction in high-elevation areas like the Tibetan Plateau?
Expectation.Answer: Using a single sediment core may not fully represent regional variations in pollen assemblages and environmental changes, given the Tibetan Plateau's vast and diverse landscape. The reliance on one core might overlook localized differences in vegetation and climate history, limiting the comprehensive understanding of past environmental conditions.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using pollen percentages versus pollen concentrations in reconstructing past vegetation and climate?
Judgmental.Answer: Pollen percentages are commonly used in reconstructions, but they can lead to problematical results, especially when arboreal pollen grains occur at high percentages in fossil pollen assemblages with low pollen concentrations. This suggests that relying solely on percentages without considering concentrations could misrepresent past vegetation and climate.

Judgmental.Question: What improvements or additional data collection techniques could enhance the quality and scope of datasets for studying past environmental changes in the Tibetan Plateau?
Judgmental.Answer: Incorporating additional proxies such as DNA analysis or isotopic studies could enhance the dataset, providing a more comprehensive understanding of past environmental changes. Additionally, expanding the spatial coverage of core samples across various lake systems might offer a broader perspective on regional environmental variations.

Assertion.Question: I'm unclear about how pollen concentrations can affect the accuracy of past vegetation and climate reconstructions.
Assertion.Answer: Arboreal pollen grains occur at high percentages in fossil pollen assemblages collected from the central Tibetan Plateau, particularly in samples with low pollen concentrations from the glacial period, which can lead to problematic results when past vegetation and climate estimations are based solely on pollen percentages without considering the variation in pollen concentrations.

Assertion.Question: I don't quite understand what specific data collection methods are employed to ensure the preservation and analysis of pollen samples over long periods.
Assertion.Answer: Pollen grains were extracted using a procedure that includes treatments with 10% HCl, 10% NaOH, and 40% HF, followed by a 7-mm mesh sieving and acetolysis treatment with a 9:1 mixture of acetic anhydride and sulfuric acid. Additionally, samples were freeze-dried before analysis, and a tablet of Lycopodium spores was added to each sample prior to pollen extraction to calculate pollen concentration.
